Variation Example: Two women both claim a child. The judge Solomon offers to cut it in half. One of the women refuses (lets go when the child is to be torn asunder, tries to stop the judge from cut-ting it) & is therefore determined to be the real mother.

Classifications: The Clever Judge & the Demon in the Pot
Variation Example: In order to possess a beautiful woman, a demon (magician) takes on the appearance of her husband & claims her as his wife. The husband & the demon argue about which is the real husband. Numerous persons are asked for advice, but nobody can distinguish between the two men. Finally a judge (clever boy [who plays at being a king or a judge], shepherd, hare, jackal, parrot) states that whichever can creep into a pot (tube) is the real husband. The husband is not able to enter, but the demon creeps inside immediately. The pot is covered, & the demon is recognized & trapped. The real husband gets his wife back.

Classifications: Purchase Not Him Who Surpasses You.
Variation Example: A father (widow) sends his son (three sons) away to learn a craft (earn money). But the boy learns to play an instrument & cards instead. When he is to be sold as slave to a merchant (when he seeks employment with a rich man) he says, “Do not buy someone who is superior to you”, or “Whoever takes me will regret it; whoever does not take me will regret it twice as much”. By his clever actions, by playing off persons against each other, by his music, & by gambling he succeeds in different situations. At the end he marries the daughter of the rich man (dealer, captain). When his father-in-law violates a king’s decree (ships are no longer allowed to shoot cannons) & is condemned to death, the youth frees him from the gallows (with three empty nutshells, which signify his father-in-law’s worth). At the end, the young man attains wealth & honor.

Classifications: Cases Solved in a Manner Worthy of Solomon
Variation Example: This misc. type comprises various tales dealing with the idea of unusual, of-ten clever, methods to determine the truth. Examples: (1) A poor man finds a purse with money in it & returns it to its owner hoping for a reward. The owner pretends that some money is missing, & that the finder took it already for his reward. The judge decides that, since the amount of money is different, the purse did not belong to the man who claimed it, & that the poor man may keep it until its rightful owner is found. (2) A judge gives sticks to all the suspects in a court case & tells them that the guilty one’s stick will grow during the night. The guilty man cuts a bit off his stick & thus is discovered. (3) Someone announces to all the people in the village that the thief has a gnat on his cap (that his cap is burning). One man reaches for his cap & thus shows himself to be the thief. (4) All the suspects are required to touch some object in the dark, & are told that the hand of the guilty one will be blackened. In fact, the object blackens any hand that touches it. The guilty man does not touch the object & is thus the only one whose hand is not blackened. (5) In order to determine which of two women is the owner of a spindle of thread, the judge asks them what the spindle is made of. Only the owner knows the right answer. (6) Disputants are ordered to fabricate a copy of the disputed ob ject (precious stone). The owner & the cheater can do so, but the false claimants cannot. (7) A man (innkeeper) whose silver has been stolen summons his guests (employees) to the table & orders them to make various ridiculous gestures. When they are all engaged in this game, he com mands them to put their heads under the table. Then he asks if the thief has head under the table. The thief answers, “Yes”.

The children of two merchants have been betrothed from childhood, but they live in different cities. The boy is given allegorical orders (if the duck has fallen into the chaff, carry her, etc.) & sent off by his father. The bride recognizes her bridegroom by these allegorical expressions.

Classifications: The Judge Appropriates the Object of Dispute
Variation Example: This misc. type comprises various tales dealing with a dispute between two parties that is decided in favor to a third person who is to judge their case. The judge either takes the contested object as evidence or destroys it. For example, two cats fight over a rice cake, & the monkey who is to decide the case eats it. A lawyer who is to decide the case of two men charges them such high fees that he is able to buy the disputed object (calf) with his earnings. The song of a bird was not meant for the plaintif but for the judge.

After spending the night with the emperor’s daughter in her chamber, her lover cannot leave without being Discovered because snow has fallen. She carries him on her back to his apartment because her own footprints are less suspect. The emperor observes this & brings the case before his advisers. To end the ensuing arguments, he permits the lovers to marry.

A man (woman) condemned to death is set free when the judge cannot solve the riddle propounded to him by the condemned person (by a relative of the condemned). The riddle refers to extraordinary or accidental events that happened to the person setting the riddle, & thus is unsolvable for outsiders. There are four main riddles: (1) Samson riddle of the living in the dead, “From the eater came forth meat & from the strong sweetness” – Swarm of bees collects honey in a lion’s carcass. (“What has seven tongues in one head?” – Bird’s nest with seven young found in a horse’s head; “Drink this wine which a bird took to its nest” – A stork took a bunch of grapes to nest, & a boy makes wine from them.) (2) Riddle of the nursing daughter, “Formerly I was daughter, now I am mother; I have a son who was the husband of my mother” – Woman has nursed her imprisoned father (woman nurses her son, wife nurses another man) through a crack in the prison wall. (3) Ilo-riddle (propounded by a woman), “Love I sit, Love I stand; Love I hold, fast in hand; I see Love, Love sees not me. Riddle me that, or hanged I’ll be” – A woman has killed her dog named Love (Ilo); from its skin shoes, gloves & a chair-covering have been made; (“With what thinks, I drink; what sees, I carry; with what eats I walk” – A woman has killed her lover, from his skull a cup has been made, from one of his eyes a ring & she carries two of his teeth in her boots). (4) Riddle of the unborn, “I am unborn; I ride the unborn (I eat the unborn)” – A boy was born by Caesarean section; he has a horse that was also born unnaturally (he eats the meat of an animal that was taken out of its dead mother’s body).

Classifications: An Execution Evaded by Using Three Wishes
Variation Example: King ordains that the guest who turns the fish on his plate (drops his knife, talks loudly) shall be executed, & also that anyone so condemned may have three wishes granted. A (young) man violates the order & pronounce his three wishes. One of the wishes is, all those who saw him turn the fish are to be blinded. All persons present pretend not to have seen anything & the accused man is freed.

Classifications: Old Saddle Granted by the King
Variation Example: A farmer does a king a good turn (a soldier claims pay for a long period of service). In return he asks for an old saddle. The unsuspecting king signs the deed of gift. Later the “old saddle” turns out to be a large estate. Nevertheless the duped king keeps his promise & gives it to him.

Classifications: Condmened Man Chooses How He Will Die
Variation Example: This misc. type comprises various tales dealing with a man condemned to death who is permitted to choose how he will die. Examples: (1) The condemed says he wants to die from old age. (2) The condemned (Seneca) chooses to open his veins & bleed to death.

A convicted man is permitted a last request be-fore he dies. He asks for strawberries although it is winter (a meal of nightingales or canaries, to learn Hebrew before he dies). Or, a barber asks to shave the judge. He puts the razor to the judge’s throat & commands him to alter the death sentence.

Classifications: The Ground is Measured with a Horse's Skin/ Ox Hide
Variation Example: A man (monk, members of a different ethnic group) asks his master for a piece of land the size of an ox’s (horse’s) hide. This is promised to him. He cuts the hide into a long thin strip which he uses to encircle a great area.

Classifications: Man Allowed to Pick Out Tree to be Hanged On
Variation Example: A man who has been condemned to death is allowed to choose the tree on which he will be hanged. He looks for a long time but cannot find one he likes. Or, he chooses one that is only knee-high (a bush, sunflower, etc.) The judge (hangman) lets him go free.
A man plants a tree even though he is told that it will never bear fruit in his lifetime. Nevertheless he plants the tree: for the next generation.
This misc. type comprises various tales dealing with the clever defense of an accused person who is finally (unexpectedly) rescued.

A beggar claims to be the brother of the king because all people descend from Adam (God). The king gives him one penny, saying that if all his brothers gave that much, he would be richer than the king himself.
A son defends his father’s behavior, saying that the man could not do any better. He learned everything from the grandfather.

This misc. type contains various tales dealing with a poor boy for whom future greatness or a marriage to a rich girl is foretold. A rich man (king, merchant, landlord) learns of the prophecy (he dreams) that a poor boy will become his son-in-law (heir). Therefore he tries to kill the boy by various plots (exposure). Finally the boy has to deliver a letter that orders his own death. The letter is exchanged (modified) by a helper, so that the boy is married to the daughter of his adversary & shares in his rank & wealth.
A man invites God to his house, but mistreats an old beggar who comes to ask for a night’s lodging. At night he hears the birds talk to the old man & as punishment learns his future.

A respected man learns by a predicition that a very young (newborn) girl will be his future wife. Not willing to marry the ugly child, he tries to kill her by stabbing her, by piercing her forehead with a needle, or by adopt-ing her in order to expose her afterwards. The girl survives, grows up, becomes very beautiful, & is married to the mafter the wedding he discovers the scar (needle) & learns from his wife’s life-history that the prediction has been ful filled despite his actions. In various regions different forms of the tale have originated : Northern cycle (Danish, Swedish, Estonian, Irish & Icelandic variants): A man witnesses the prediction of his future, tries to kill the girl in various ways by exposing her in water, by nailing her by her hands to a tree, or by sending her out with a letter that orders her death. The girls survives, marries the man, & is finally recognized by her scars as the predestined wife. Southern cycle with a wide regional dispersion (Greek, Slovene, English, Scottish, Irish, Estonian, Spanish & Brazilian variants): The marriage of the fated child is combined with the further condition: A ring that had been thrown into the water has to be found again. The ring is finally located in a fish’s belly.

A prophecy (dream) foretells that a certain newborn child will kill his father & marry his mother. In order to avoid this fate, the child (Oedipus) is exposed. The boy is rescued & reared by shepherds (he grows up at a strange king’s court). There he unwittingly kills his father (who was employed as a gardener) whom he did not recognize. Upon the king’s advice he marries the wife of the dead man & learns later that she is his own mother.

This misc. Type comprises various tales (with legendary traits) dealing with a person who kills his father (parents). Examples: (1) A father reproaches his son for his dissolute life, & the son kills him. A saint protects the sinner from despair & leads him to repent & do penance for his crime. (2) It is prophesied that a certain child (Judas) will bring great sorrow to humanity. The child is exposed but is adopted & raised by a childless queen. When she gives birth, the adopted child murders her child & flees to Jerusalem. When he steals apples in a garden he is caught there by the owner. He kills the owner & marries his widow, who is (although he does not know this) his own mother. (3) It is prophesied that a certain young man (Julianus Hospitator) will murder his parents. He flees in order to avoid this, & marries. His parents search for him & come to his house, where his wife invites them to rest in their marriage bed. When the son arrives home & sees two people in his bed, he thinks his wife is unfaithful to him & kills both of his parents. When he learns what he has done, he repents & does penance. His sin is forgiven. Or, a young man kills his parents (father only) because a false adviser has lied to him, saying that his wife is an adulteress. (4) After his wife dies, a lord falls in love with his own daughter. She gives birth to a son (Albanus), who is exposed. He is rescued & raised by a childless king. When the boy grows up, he becomes king himself. His natural father hears about this young king & marries his daughter to him. Before the adoptive father dies, he tells the young man what he knows about his origins. The young man’s wife realizes that she has married her own son. After the king dies, the three others go to the bishop & confess their sins. They are required to do penance for seven years. On their way home, they spend the night in a forest, & the father & daughter renew their incestuous relationship. Albanus discovers this & kills them both. He becomes a hermit, is killed, & later becomes a saint. (5) A drunken man spends the last of his money. The devil prom-ises to make him rich if he will murder his own parents, but the man refuses. The devil gives him money anyway, & tells him to restrict his binges of drunkenness to one day each week. The man disobeys, gets drunk every day, & murders his parents.

The son of an incestuous union is abandoned. His mother adds ivory tablets that describe the circumstances of his birth. The boy is saved, baptized by the abbot Gregorius who gives him his own name, & grows up in the monastery. At the age of 15, the child Gregorius learns about his mys terious origins & leaves in order to find his real parents. Unwittingly Gregorius reaches his native country where his un-married mother rules. When he saves her from a neighboring ruler’s unwelcome advances, she agrees to marry Gregorius. He has no idea that she is his mother. When she finds the tablets with the history of his origins she discloses her identity. In order to expiate the unwitting incest, she lives a pious life. Gregorius undertakes a pilgrimage as penance. At his request a fisher -man fetters his ankles with chains to a rock in the sea & throws the key into the water. Seventeen years later Gregorius is chosen by an angel as successor of the deceased pope. Messengers from Rome look for Gregorius & arrive at the fisherman’s hut. In a fish prepared for the guests, the key for his chains is found. Gregorius is elected pope, & when he enters Rome healing miracles take place. His mother makes a pilgrimage to Rome in order to confess her sins to the pope. They recognize each other. She enters a convent. After their death both gain spiritual salva tion (Gregorius is worshiped as saint).

This misc. type com prises various tales dealing with the prediction of a person’s death. Examples: The time & manner of the future death of a newborn child (adult) is forecast by norns (nurse, judge, etc.; in dream). The parents of the child overhear the prophecy (they learn it from another person). Different manners of death are predicted: Death by natural forces (storm, thunderstorm, falling tree), by an animal (wolf, tiger, snake, horse), by drowning, when drinking water, when shearing sheep, by poisoning, on the wedding day, by hanging. The three-fold death of a person caused by e.g. starving, burning & drowning is prophecied. Various precautions are taken in order to evade fate (the person is immured in a wall, isolated, hidden in a tower). Nevertheless the prophecy is fulfilled. In some variants the predestined fate is averted (by a helper, step mother, eagle)

A mother mourns for her dead children. When she goes to church she realizes that the mass is being performed by dead relatives. Then she is shown at the altar what the evil fates of her children would have been (one son is on gallows, the other one is bound to a wheel) if they had not died. She thanks God for having taken her children.

An only son goes into military service & wants to take vengeance on the officers who recruited him. An old man (God) shows in spirit a newborn child with a gun & uniform. Now the youth understands that God has determined everyone’s fate.

A man overhears the fate predestined by a god (goddess, soothsayer) decreeing that a boy (prince) will spend his life in poverty but will always own an ox (kill a stag every day) & that his sister will become a prostitute. When the boy grows up, the man advises him to sell his ox every day so that the god must furnish him a new one each day (to wait inside his hut so that the god must bring the stag to him). He advises the girl to demand a handful of pearls for her favors. The god must come in disguise each day because no man can pay such a price. The god soon tires of his duties & agrees to reverse the decrees of fate.

A man fleeing from a unicorn falls into a well where a dragon lives. A tree grows beside the well, and, as he falls, the man grasps one of its branches. He finds two mice, one black & one white, gnawing at the branch, & sees snakes at the base of the tree. Observing all this, the man forgets his perilous position. When a drop of honey falls from the crown of the tree, he reaches to taste it (reaches for money that lies near him). The branch breaks & the man falls into the jaws of the dragon.
An astrologer prophesies that a certain ruler will die within a year, but that he himself will live another twenty years. A knight kills the astrologer, thus discrediting his prophecies.

This misc. type consists of various tales dealing with the origin of death and/or the time of death. Examples: (1) Formerly God let human beings die & return to life, but the moon died forever. A goat (hare) was sent by men to tell God that they wished to continue to live in this way. But the goat con founded the messages, & the dog arrived too late to change it. Since that time, humans die forever. (2) God sends out a chameleon to tell humans that they should live forever (continue to live after death). On the way the chameleon is overtaken by a faster animal that delivers the opposite message. (3) Formerly Death walked along singing, but he did not enter the houses of men. An old woman listened to him, liked his song, & repeated it. Thereupon Death followed the woman to her house & bedroom, & when she lay down (to have sexual inter-course) he strangled her. This is how Death first entered the houses of men. (4) In the year before they were to die, people neglected their responsibilities (they repaired their fences with temporary materials). Therefore, God decided that they should not know in advance when they will die.

Classifications: The Time Has Come but Not the Man.
Variation Example: A water spirit shouts three times from a river, “The hour has passed & the man did not come”. The call is heard far outside the town. A young person runs to the river & drowns.

A lazy (stupid) son leaves home & dissipates his fortune abroad. He becomes a soldier & asks his father for money by sending him a (three) letter pretending to have become a lieutenant (captain). The deception is discovered & the father expels his son. Through a trick (cleverness, magic) the young man makes his fortune & becomes king by marrying a princess. Rich & mighty, he decides to return home. On the way he is held up by robbers (he gambles away all his belongings). His com-panions are all killed, & he himself escapes, but he has to aban-don his royal clothes. When he reaches his parents’ home in humble clothing, his father accuses him of lying & punishes & humiliates him (by forcing him to tend pigs, goats, sheep, geese). His wife (disguised as hermit, priest, bishop) follows him, (overwhelms the robbers) & rescues him from the difficult situation. He then puts on his royal clothes, returns home, & proves his royal identity to his parents.
A merchant’s stepson is sent to sea & makes his fortune. The merchant’s own son, living protected at home, has bad luck.

(Hasan of Basra.) A man hires himself out to a merchant (landlord) who promises high payment for unspecified labor. The merchant leads him to a high (golden) mountain that cannot be climbed. He (drugs him and) sews him up in an animal skin. Big birds carry him to the mountaintop as prey. There he slips out of the skin & throws precious stones (gold) down to the merchant. Later the merchant leaves him, helpless, behind on the mountain. Through lucky circumstances (passage under the earth, plunge into the sea) he escapes. Later he takes service with the same em-ployer. When they arrive at the mountain again, the merchant is tricked into the animal skin & is carried up the mountain. After disclosing his identity to the merchant, the workman makes him throw precious stones down in the same way he had done before. Then he leaves the merchant on the mountain where he dies.

Placidas, a colonel of the emperor Trajan, hunts a deer, between whose antlers a cross disclosed it to be Christ in animal form. His wife has a similar vision. Both are baptized together with their two sons. Placidas is named Eustacius, his wife Theopiste . When Eustacius rides again to the place of the vision, the deer reappears. Christ prophesies for him a period of suffering similar to that of Job. He can choose if he wishes to have the suffering now or at the end of his life. Eustacius decides to have it soon. When his servants & his animals die & all his property is stolen, he escapes with his family to Egypt. A boatman claims his wife as payment for the ferry; when Eustacius crosses a river with his two sons, the boys are carried off by a lion & a wolf. Farmers & shepherds take the animals’ prey & raise the boys. Eustacius works as farmhand. Many years later Eustacius is found by a legation of the emperor. They persuade him to return. When serving as colonel, he recovers his sons & his wife by chance. The new emperor in Rome wants them to make sacrifices to idols. When they identify them-selves as Christians, the new emperor Hadrian orders them to be thrown to the lions, but the wild animals do not touch them. Then they are pushed into a red-hot iron bull. Their uninjured bodies are buried by Christians; on the grave a church is built.

Classifications: Master Discovers That the Slave Girl He Wants to Marry is a Near Relative
Variation Example: A man (prince, farmer’s son, master) intends to marry a beautiful girl (slave, servant) (after having redeemed her). She turns out to be his sister.
A girl has to choose if she prefers to suffer in youth or in old age. She decides to suffer in youth & has to endure a long series of misfortunes. Finally she has good fortune.

A married couple has to choose if they prefer to suffer in youth or in old age. They decide to endure hardship in youth. The husband sells his wife (voluntarily, by force). The money is carried off by a bird. As a workman in a foreign land, he Discovers the lost money in a felled tree in which the bird had built its nest. He is brought before the widowed queen, who recognizes him as her first husband. In some Jewish variants a couple can choose if they want seven good years now or in the future. The woman decides to have it now in order to educate her children. They receive money, most of which they give away as charity. At the end they are told that their good deeds have compensated for the bad years ahead.

A king offends a deity. He loses his kingdom & his fortune & is forced to wander for years in poverty. His wife is stolen from him. He must labor at menial tasks. Taken in & helped by a friend, he sees a valuable necklace disappear before his eyes. Knowing he will be suspected of the theft, he flees. He is bought as a slave & is ordered to throw corpses into a tank for a fee. His wife brings the corpse of their son. The king is eventually restored to his former position. His wife (and child) are restored to him.
